text: Can thanks to travlr. Really great beer. Black brown with tan head poured from a can. Aroma is rich nutty roasty coffee and light bready malts. Taste is balanced sweetness and roast with really nice coffee flavor. Surprisingly great stuff.

Pour is a black with a large tan head. Aroma is of bitter chocolate and a huge roasted coffee. Flavor is a bitter bakers chocolate with more of the rich roasted coffee. This is what all coffee stouts should taste like. Very bitter and rich with plenty of coffee. Probably not a coffee forward as some of the Founders coffee beers but this is right up there with the coffee rich flavor.
Can from Bruisin Ales. Nice coffee and chocolate aroma. Oreo cookie crumbs. Rich smooth taste of coffee and chocolate and roasted grains. Great stout.
This is nice mild coffee stout. The color is dark and the coffee is tasty and aromatic. The balance is great as its not too boozy. Great beer and well done.

Combined notes draft and bottled. Pours dark brown to black in color with a small khaki colored head. The aroma and flavor have big roasted coffee, chocolate, roasted malt, earthy bitterness, nothing too fancy here just a solid coffee stout.

Pours a pitch black body, head is a tan color. Head retention is average and so is lacing. 

Smell is similar to cold brewed coffee. Notes of green coffee beans, oil, and fresh roasted, charred beans are prevalent. This smells like I stepped into a roastery. Slight notes of chocolate are present, hops and alcohol arent detected. 

Taste is big on coffee, acidic and slightly bitter. Getting some green herbaceous notes also. Biscuit malts are in the mix along with charred oak. Beer ends with a hint of chocolate, alcohol and hops are light. 

Mouthfeel is medium bodied and well carbonated. Unfortunately head died quickly, leaving something to be desired. Beer leaves a slight astringency in the aftertaste. 

Overall this was a very tasty coffee stout. In your face coffee flavors, no chocolate, caramel, vanilla/bourbon to mask it. A bit on the bitter spectrum of coffee but I can appreciate the raw flavors which is becoming rarer these days.
Can. Aroma is iced coffee, hint of sweetness. Taste is coffee, unsweetened baking cocoa. Medium body, somewhat milky feel, albeit skim milk. For a stout thats only 6.8% it packs a lot of flavor.

One of my favories from Pisgah. Pours appropriately dense and opaque. Solid reddish tan head with decent lacing. This one is all coffee- like really good cold brew infused into really good beer. If I had to find a fault, could call it one dimensional, but it is a coffee stout, after all. Nice roasty/ burnt notes, chocolate, raisin and plum all in background. Bitter at the end (in a hops way, not coffee way) and a nice full mouthfeel with low carbonation. Delicious.

Refrigerated brown bomber poured into a snifter. Pours black with small dark brown highlights and small light brown head. Aroma is nice coffee, medium body, low carbonation, and no lacing. Taste is nice rich coffee. One of the best coffee stouts I have had, a little carbonation up front and then almost still.

Bottle via trade with b3shine-- thanks Beau!-- and shared with Parksy and Grippitis. Hearty, near-black pour, dense light brown head. Rich coffee aroma, roast and chocolate too. Thick body, fudgey, roasty, with deep rich coffee flavour. This is on par with DDCs Aphro! Fantastic!
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: Draft at the source during RBWG. Hazy brwon color, brown head. Nice aroma of baking brownies. Taste has coffee, chocolate, edge of burnt brownies. Tasty.

Sample from a 22 oz. brought by Drew to Ale Alpharetta. Pours dark brown, with a small, tan head. The aroma is strong coffee, caramel, and cocoa. Malty sweet, with a strong, roasted bitterness, and an unpleasant soured flavor. Medium body, chalky, and thin. Overall, this stout has far too much coffee in the aroma, to the detriment of any other aromas. Maybe its just because I dont like coffee, but I thought it tasted off.

July Ale Alpharetta. For "just" a stout this felt like a monster imperial. Beautiful mocha lasting head on top of a thick black body. Lots of dark chocolate and thick black coffee with a semi sweet and moderately bitter lingering finish. Good stuff.

Keg @ Pisgah during RBWG, Asheville. The pours brown with a small head. Dark roasted espresso. Ashy wood. Some cream. Sweet coffee cake flavor. Toffee, dark chocolate. Cinnamon character. Medium body, sweet and supple. Pleasing stuff.

On tap at Pisgah during RBWG. Black color. Nice thin light brown head. Couple dots of lace. Awesome big coffee nose, good dark chocolate. Nice, bigger chewy body. Smooth, lighter carbonation. Lightly dry finish. Good moderate bitter taste, light sweet. Bittersweet. Awesome big coffee aroma, way bigger coffee aroma than the ABV might suggest. Fantastic coffee stout.

Draft sampled at Wild South Brewfest. I should have learned long ago that I dont like coffee stouts. But this one embodied more of what I dont like in them: stale, dank coffee grounds and a burnt bitterness. A shame too, because the roasted barley and the light smokiness would have made for a nice stout.
Bottle. Pours black with brown head. Nose and taste of roast coffee, espresso bean, vegetal notes and lightly soured chocolate. Medium body.

2014 RBWG Draft at the brewery.
Pours black with a tan head.
Aroma of dark roasted coffee beans.
Dry coffee flavor.

Taster at Pisgah during RBWG. More of that Manhattan Special coffee-soda flavor I got in the Burial Doughnut but slightly more earthy. Actually its more like iced coffee concentrate you make by letting coffee grains soak in cold water overnight, but that stuff is good.
On tap at Pisgah. Pours a deep brown color with white head. Burnt, black coffee grounds flavors. Black coffee grounds flavor - solid.
Bottle thanks to Bruce! Pours a dark brown with beige head. The aroma is strong coffee bean and roast. Medium mouthfeel with rich coffee and light dry finish. Good.
Sample at the brewery. If you like coffee you will love this beer. It is very much a one dimensional beer. However, the coffee is tasty. oh, a bit of smokiness.
On tap @ source. Pours a dark brown appearance and head. Heavy ashy, smoked roasty malty aroma. Chocolate offered. Bitter earthy flavor. Some slight sweetness. Ashy flavor. OK.
Draft at brew pub opaque black. Nose nice medium roast coffee. Taste sweet and coffee up front. Coffee carries through mid palate. Nice roast and bitter finish.

On tap at the brewery. Dark pour with a brown head. This beer is pretty much all about the coffee. Aroma of cold pressed quality coffee. Taste is espresso without the espresso bitterness. Smooth, tasty, I like!
Bomber to glass. Pours a rich dark black with a thick creamy head. Smells of dynamite coffee. Tastes like a cold coffee and has a thick mouthfeel. Nicely done Pisgah!

Immediate smell of coffee and malts. Pours black with thick tan foam. Coffee, malt with very slight sweetness and easy on palate with coffee after tone. This is a really nice and must try. Give it a go wont you.
Awesome stout from Asheville NC, good coffee stout very good stuff, thank you US airways

Excellent coffee beer from yet another solid brewery in Asheville, NC. One of their staple beers that will get you desiring to try more from this establishment. Medium to dark amber pour with overwhelming hints of coffee. Highly recommend.

Tap @ Pisgah. Coffee black pour. Aroma of cold brewed, fresh roasted coffee beans. Flavor of burnt malt sugars , sweet coffee beans, earthy notes. Finishes with a mellow coffee character, smooth balance, no heavy bitterness. (3906)

Bomber thanks to crajun. Pours pitch black with a huge foamy head that fades slowly and leaves nice lacing. Aroma is fresh coffee beans with some light chocolate. Taste has a very nice fresh coffee taste but theres an odd metalic taste too. Finishes very bitter and dry. Great aroma but the taste is off.
22oz bottle shared @RBWG-JAX-lt brown-brown. A-roasty/coffee-dk malt. T-follows. 3.8

Bomber shared. Pours dark brown with mocha colored head. Big coffee and roasted malt nose, just want to spend time smelling this one. If you like coffee you will like this beer. The flavor starts off with lots of roasted malts and then finishes strong with the coffee as it ends. Finsihes dry. Excellent coffee stout.

From 22oz bottle. 

Pours almost black with minimal head. Aroma more like cold coffee than beer (not too out of line for a coffee stout, I suppose). Tastes of coffee infused beer, but not with the delightful combination of flavors a good coffee stout will have. 

I'd have to say this one is a disappointment. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle. Pours a near black color with a small tan head that disappears quite quickly. Nose is dark and roasty with coffee being quite forward on this beer; however, I get a little bit of dark fruit coming through subtly underneath. Taste has a lot of coffee in there with just a hint at some sourness on the back end. Nice drink.

Black color with a beige head. Aroma is strong ass coffee and dark chocolate. Flavor is full of espresso with some milk chocolate. Oh yeah. Well balanced bad ass impy stout. Sweet finish and complex. Awesome stuff.

Poured into a pint glass out of a 22oz bomber.

Pours pitch black with a one finger dark tan head. Very good head retention with ok lacing.

Aroma is all about the coffee. Lots of medium roast coffee with hints of dark chocolate and dark roasted malt. Some caramel in there too. It is really hard to get past the coffee, though, but it is inviting.

The taste is more and more coffee. Some milk chocolate and caramel/toffee. Really the perfect blend of coffee and chocolate with no one character being too overpowering. Bitterness is very light but this beer is not too sweet either so it balances out nicely.

Overall, a very well done beer from Pisgah. Wish I would have picked up more than one.

Bottle at the JPBP Gathering 2013: Basically opaque with lasting creamy tan head. The aroma has notes of coffee, roast, chocolate, caramel., plum, resin and pine needles. The taste is a lovely blend of bittering hops and bitter coffee balanced by sweet chocolate and caramel malts. Earthy and lightly charred as well. The mouth feel is lush and oily but not too heavy, slightly ashy on the finish. Nom Nom!!! I liked this one a lot.

Valdez Stout on tap at the brewery (from notes).  This has more coffee than malt; excellent sweet bitter balance. The body is a tad over carbonated but smooth. Exceptionally durable beige head.
Rather like a strong Kona.Pipeline Porter.

Bottle shared on the RBWG 2013 bus - I think I can thank the Turd for this one? Pours oily black-brown with a creamy tan head. Rich coffee aroma, some dark fruits. Medium sweet flavor with rich coffee and moderate earthy bitterness. Very good balance. Medium bodied with fine carbonation. Lightly roasty to finish, some dark toast, great coffee character. I like it a lot.

Bottle from Justin. Thin and coffee would be two words to describe this beer. I'm trying to figure out how this is rated close to Blackout Stout. Anyway, aroma and flavor are, surprise thin stout and coffee. Some roastiness, but not near enough malt in this one to keep my attention. Noticed a good amount of carb going down. Ok beer. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle shared on the RBWG bus tour to hell 
Appearance: Dark brown with a small tan head and some lacing  
Roasted malts, smokey, chocolate and vanilla 
Nice and tasty

Bottle thanks to Turdferguson at RBWG! Pours an opaque black from the bottle with thin tan head and light lace. Aroma and taste of coffee, slight dark chocolate, coffee, roasted malt, and more coffee; dry, thick finish on the mouth. Definitely a coffee stout, but definitely nice for breakfast.

651mL shared by TURDFERGUSON at RBWG. Pours inkier black than expected, deeper mocha head. Nose is big coffee, goaty, gamey/animal, pretty green overall. Taste is very nice- roasty, silky, savory, steak fat, peppercorn. Lemon coffee acidity in back end. Pretty good stuff.
2/22/13. 22oz bottle on RBWG bus! Black pour with a small tan head. Nice bold aroma and flavor with lots of coffee and bits of sweetened chocolate. Nice!
Bomber to taster (thanks turdferguson). Looks good; pitch black with beige lacing. Smells and tastes solid; coffee and dark malt with an exceptionally smooth mouthfeel. A great example of the style.

Pours a pitch black with a medium mocha head.  Aroma has loads of nice coffee...hint of sweetness and a hint of roasty smoke.  Flavor has some sweet coffee notes, nuttiness, dark fruit, and nice mild roasty smoke.  Mouthfeel is light and the finish is dry roasty coffee.

Draft at Trailhead. Pours black with an inch of khaki head which leaves lacing.  Big, beautifully roasted coffee on the nose. Big coffee on the tongue as well but its not a coffee bomb. Finishes clean. When people think of craft beer, this is what theyre talking about.

Im not a big coffee fan some that stouts that accent Coffee primarily always get me.  This one is not quite like narwhal or big bad but its upfront coffee with nothing else coming through.  Thankfully I just shared it but it still wasnt bad.

The aroma is very coffee like with burnt malt, molasses, and licorice. The appearance is almost black with a small head. The taste is like the aroma. The palate is smooth. Overall just an average stout.
Its definitely very toasty with the aspect of the style. has a roasted flavor with a slight tart twang at the end. its bitterness is not the focus but is more of an after thought,

Bottle from hobbie100. Thanks Richard!

I shared this with some good friends while watching football. Good times.

A: Valdez appears deep, dark brown in color with a half inch of beige head. The head displays good retention and leaves some nice lacing on the glass.

S: Fabulous aroma, primarily of coffee, followed by roasted malt and chocolates.

T: The taste was also terrific. Valdez is all about the coffee. The flavor is robust and grand, with a variety of chocolates and roasted malt emerging behind the dominant coffee taste.

M: Smooth and creamy with a healthy level of carbonation. Well done.

D: A superb example of a coffee stout. I highly recommend Pisgah Valdez.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 01-07-2011

2010 bottle acquired via trade.  Pours dark brown with a wispy espreaao head.  Aroma is strong coffee, dark chocolate, fudge, dried cherries.  Taste is sweet with a hint of oxidation.  Medium bodied and slick.  Pretty good.

Originally reviewed: 4/23/10. Super excited to try this big beer from the boys at Pisgah. Poured into a snifter glass. Pours a thick viscous black with no head on top at all. Nothing. Big roasted coffee scents burst out. This is strong right after popping the cap. Lots of espresso, some milk chocolate, cream, toasted sugar. This smells great. A very good lead-in to drinking this bad boy.

The mouth is very crisp and bubbly...too much so. For this style I prefer big and heavy, as this one is, but it needs to be smoother and a little creamier. Too much carbonation going on. Great roasted coffee flavors all over this. Excellent bitter black coffee balanced with a creamy milky chocolate on the end. Slight grassy hops noted on the finish as well. I like that touch. It claimed to be a coffee beer, and a coffee beer it was. Wow. 

*Note: This was my third "coffee" beer in a row (all different styles), and this one was my favorite for sure. One of the best coffee beers Ive had in awhile.

Pours black in color with a finger of tan head.  A bit of spicy coffee to go along with lots of roasted malt and maybe a hint of dark chocolate.  There is just a bit of vanilla type sweetness.  The flavor is slightly sweet but still fairly heavy on the coffee, which adds a little bit of spiciness.  Lots of roasted malt and a bit of dark chocolate.  Just an okay coffee stout.

I received this bottle in a huge in person trade with thagr81us down in SC in September. Thanks for hitting this want Calton!

This beer pours a dark chocolate brown I color with a one finger beige head. It poured medium in body. The aromas are rich of fresh coffee grounds and bitter chocolate. The nose is actually quite similar to that of Founders Breakfast Stout. The flavors too, pretty similar to FBS. the coffee and chocolate are both there Ina knock you upside the head type of manner. This beer just isnt nearly as smooth or full in body as FBS but the flavor is very close. Im taken aback by this one. Its a phenomenal coffee stout and definitely worth trying. This is definitely a beer to seek out.

Bottle shared by Peter at STL RB gathering.  Pour is almost black with a thin tan head.  Aroma and flavor are loaded with coffee and ash with hints of sweet, lightly fruity malt. This is a pretty bold offering and certainly one that coffee lovers should try. A little bit messy, but still worth trying.

22 oz. bottle via trade. Pours a mostly opaque coffee brown with a tan ring for a head. The aroma is a big blast of coffee, and a lot of it. Really rich, gritty, and roasty. The flavor tones it down a little and adds some dark fruits, earth, and vegetal notes. Medium-bodied, with a roasty, gritty mouthfeel and moderate carbonation. Something was just a wee bit off in the flavor and palate. Otherwise, if you like your coffee stouts, this is for you.

Sampled at the StL RB gathering.  It poured a black color with a tan head. The aroma was of coffee with some malt and chocolate. The taste was of  some malt and chocolate with a bunch of coffee, both dry and bitter.

Tasted from cool-looking tall bottle at 2nd STL Ratebeer Gathering, thanks phaleslu. Poured an opaque, super dark brown color. Tan foam subsided quickly. Strong aromas of coffee, malt far beneath, nothing else. Flavor was entirely coffee. Heavy body but with higher than usual carbonation as well. Aftertaste eventually dried to a more typical stout profile, but overall this beer is too one-dimensional. They definitely put the coffee in coffee stout. Nonetheless, I appreciate all the organic ingredients.
(bottle - sampled at STL RB Gathering) black with tan head. Roast malt and coffee aroma. Flavor is toasted malt and lots of bitter coffee.

Pours a deep black with good carbonation for a stout and an ample tan head. The nose is a little unusual. Its somewhat typical for the style, with roasted coffee notes, but there is a mustiness I cant get past. Flavor is coffee, roasted malt, and wood with a surprising acidity. The mouthfeel may be a bit thin, but not too bad. A pretty solid if not outstanding offering.

Comes out of the tap a deep, opaque sable barely a kitten whisker above solid black with a fine-bubbled tan head. Rich, smoky aroma has strong chocolate and quality coffee tones and screams DRINK ME!!! to anybody who appreciates good stouts. Flavor is strongly like high-quality roast coffee with tones of unsweet chocolate, caramel and burnt wood plus a hint of molasses. Full-bodied texture has a strong, persistent tingle and leaves a smoky mocha finish. A must!!!

Tasted on 12/14/11 from a 22oz bomber bottle obtained in a trade, there is no date in the bottle, but this one has been in the cellar (unintentionally) for over a year.  Pours completely opaque black with a thin tan head that leaves nothing more than a thin collar of lace.  The nose is dark and roasted with freshly roasted coffee with chocolate aromas that range from dark to milk, with a lightly creamy note.  The flavor is lightly sweet Oreo with tons of fresh coffee, dark and milk chocolate, and some nutty flavors.  The body is full and creamy with average carbonation and a long roasted coffee and creamy milk chocolate finish.

Pours pitch black with faint mahogany edges and a one finger beige head that immediately fades into a thin ring.  Sporadic spots of lacing left behind.  
Rosted coffee bean aroma with lots of dark roasted malt and coffee presence. Gourmet coffee is prominent with a nice roastiness without smelling overdone or burnt.  Hints of hazelnut, toffee, chocolate and toast.  Slight liactic cream presence.  

Medium bodied with a blast of smooth, deep roasted coffee that dominates the flavor but never becomes overpowering, abrasive, acrid or burnt.  Hints of hazelnut and toffee as well as some bittersweet dark chocolate and a slight lactic creaminess that balances things out while adding to the palate.  Perfectly balanced and extremely quaffable.  One of the best coffee beer Ive had.

22oz btl  pours dark with coffee (Dynamite Roasting Company) hitting you in face first smelling touches of barnyard, chocolate, roasty coffee 
Appearance black, brown, brown foam, rocky head, 
Taste of iced coffee, burnt sugar light sweetness, medium bitterness, big roasty full body, creamy, average carbonation, long finish,

Draft @ the brewery. Pours a black color with a small tan head. Has a roasted malty coffee aroma with weak chocolate hints. Roasted malty coffee and chocolate flavor. Has a roasted malty coffee finish.

tried a sample of this last night at redlight. pours black with a medium brown head. roasted coffee flavor, dark fruit. mookah, vanilla taste. coffee beans. palate lacks a bit but not surprising considering the abv. i like it.

Big thanks to Huhzubendah for providing this bottle.

Pours near black with a good mocha head and a bit of a thin cap as it makes its way down the glass. The nose is really full of chocolate with a good amount of roast and coffee there as well. The chocolate really rips through everything else and is quite enjoyable. The taste is the same. There is some roast and coffee in the background, but there is a diverse array of chocolate types coming through. Milk, semi-sweet, and dark all seem to make their way into the mix. Pretty full, rich body. Really an enjoyable drinking experience. Thanks again, fellow Mid-Atlantic Bears fan.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 01-04-2011

22 ounce bottle. Pours a pure black color with a medium brown head. A sweet roasted coffee nose, some fruit. The flavor is mostly a rich roasted coffee, milky, sweet, some vanilla. Very dry and well made.

Bottle provided by Nate, drank from my Hill Farmstead glass... Dark brown with a nice light tan head, good retention and lacing... The aroma is tons of fresh coffee, has the Intelligentsia of HBI... The taste is equally nice, good light coffee but its fresh. Super easy to drink.

Bottle from peabodies in Boone, NC.  Dark brown pour with a beige head. Aroma is roasty,  coffee, and chocolate.  Silky body.  Creamy with hints of bakers chocolate, coffee, and roast.  Fresh coffee lingers.  Very nice

Draft at brewer. Jet black pour with a brown head. Scent of coffee and roastiness! Taste of coffee and chocolate with a hint of vanilla. An outstanding porter! Cant wait to open a bomber I got and compare!

Poured into a snifter. Not quite sure how 6.8% ABV justifies the "imperial" designation, but whatever.

4.0 A: Light black in color if that makes any sense. Two fingers of frothy light brown head with not quite average retention and not really any lacing.

5.0 S: Awesome! I had no idea this was a coffee stout. Given that, Im bumping the appearance from a 3.5 to a 4 since I know how coffee does a number on head retention. Perfect coffee aroma - in my face, yet not overbearing. Instead of being balance with sweetness, theres more roastiness behind it in the form of roasted barley. As it warms, semi-sweet chocolate and rich caramel come out. Excellent.

3.5 T: Im loving the coffee in the taste, but its much more one dimensional than the nose. There just isnt enough of anything else to balance the powerful coffee. This is understandable given my qualms with the mouthfeel. The coffee covers up whatever else is in there.

2.5 M: Light body. With a thicker body this one would have been a lot better. The extra residual sugar would also have balanced out the coffee taste. Carbonation is a bit higher than Id like as well, but that is trivial compared to the body problem.

3.0 D: This beer could be fabulous if they upped the mouthfeel to a medium or thicker body. Although I love the strong coffee flavor, it needs some strong malts to supplement it.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 09-15-2010 02:05:08

Bottled. RBESG 2010. 
Black colour with a persistent tan head. Aroma from green pepper, coffee beans, chocolate and lastly tad licorice. Mouthfeel is very soft with suggestions of pepper and chocolate up front and then caramel and licorice in the background. The pepper is a bit disturbing to me personally.

Bottle. Aroma very coffee-forward, super fresh coffee, fresh enough that maybe its just my imagination (I dont know how these things work), but I feel like Im picking up complexities of vanilla and tobacco, amongst others that Im too inept to name, from the coffee itself. If thats actually the case, thats some pretty bitchin coffee that retains its character so well in the beer. Flavor has a sweet roast and full (but not syrupy) body reminding me this is still beer. This must be a super fresh bottle, and it shows that they certainly know how to let the coffee shine, and sure picked some great coffee for the job.

Bottle.  Pours black with a small tan head.  Aroma of fresh coffee beans, peanut butter, burnt roasted malt.  Flavor of roasted coffee beans, roasted and burnt malts, a touch of peanut butter and bitter chocolate, vanilla, mocha, light cream.  Awesome coffee stout, this is what a coffee stout should be!   Probably the best coffee stout Ive ever had.  (I am now seriously regretting only buying 1 bottle of this)
9/4/10/5/19 [4.7/5]

Really nice opaque black pour with a deep 4-finger chocolate head that leaves a thick cap and generous chunky lace.  The nose is of roasted dark chocolates, leaves the room smelling of a wonderful coffee house.  Flavors are malty, semi-sweet, with roasts coming through a lavish dark chocolate, tons of coffee beans and freshly-roasted coffee.  The finish closes with just a hint of roasted cherry.... and lots of coffee bean.  The body is smooth and semi-creamy, providing an easy quaff to the palate, and has a silky body that is excellent.  This one is spot on for java lovers, and is a gorgeous winter evening offering on this occasion.  Just great, really.

22 oz bottle sent to me by my 2010 winter Secret Santa. Pour is hazed black brown with a smallish khaki head. Aroma is all coffee initially, a bit of a stale coffee aroma, though the char and roast behind are nice. Taste is the stale coffee, followed by a bit of pine, finishing with char ash and a mineral aftertaste. Palate is medium, dry, clean mineral finish.  Thanks for sending this one my way, Santa.

This was a simply outstanding beer. Good amount of coffee in the aroma and flavor. Almost felt like I was actually drinking coffee at one point. Also got a little bit of chocolate and vanilla in there on the back end. A great beer!!

Bottle. Poured into a New Belgium glass a dark brown color with a nice 1 finger tan head that settles to form a coaster. Roasted coffee, malts, tobacco, and leather dominate the nose. Medium mouthfeel. pretty velvety. Slightly sweet flavor soon gives way to a nice roasted coffee flavor that linger on for a while. Not the best coffee stout I have had but not bad either.

Well made beer but a little too heavy on the coffee for my liking. Great mouthfeel and easy to drink with the alcohol well hidden. Not disappointed just not overly impressed. Just take a cold cup of black coffee and pour it into your stout..you get the picture.

Sampled @ GABF!  Just wasnt a huge fan of this.  Hershey syrup colored pour with a creamy latte head.  Lots of bitter roasted coffee, a little ash, and nuttiness.  Flavor similar...just not very well rounded...one dimensional.  Meh.

Black with a lasting tan head. Aroma of licorice, spice, dark chocolate and ash-y roast malt. Rich flavour of dark chocolate, licorice, dried fruits and caramelized sugar. The coffee doesnt seem to get in the way of a well composed strong stout

Pours slow and fills the immediate area with immense coffee like aroma.  It has changed a bit each year since being created.  For the most part, it has been the coffee beans used that has changed.  I have enjoyed them all each and ever year.  One of the finest coffee stouts I have had.  Strong coffee tones unlike other coffee stouts that have more of a hint.  Worth buying.

6th June 2010. RBESG 10 Grand Tasting at the Brasserie 4:20 Warehouse. Very dark brown beer. Frothy tan head. Smooth dry palate. Nice mix of dark chocolate and coffee. Finishes a little dry. Not the most sumptuos coffee stout ever but a pretty decent beer.

Bottle at RBESG Rome Grand Tasting. Black colour, light brown head. Aroma of coffee, hard roasted malts, chocolate. Flavour is sweet, chocolate, nice coffee, hard roasted malts, light fruity, good coffee bitter finish. Medium bodied. Lovely coffee stout.
Bottle. Pitch black with a creamy tan head. The aroma is pure cold coffee, let caramel, chocolate and sweet malt. The flavour is frappe, coffee, chocolate and sweet malt. Creamy texture.
bottlt at RBESG 2010... dark black ... thin tan head ... coffeee .... light roast ... nose soft cold coffee roast ... light toffee ... little charcoal

Bomber. Mmmm, coffee is good. It smells like pure, rich coffee, is pitch black, and has a small dark, dense head. Hits up front with lots of coffee, then some nice brown sugar and caramel and a bit of a bitterness in the finish. Theres a somewhat acidic finish, but fairly clean. Great beer as long as you love coffee.

UPDATED: JUN 10, 2010 Bottle @ Copenhaniacs tasting, Pt.1. Pours unclear dark brown with a small lasting creamy head. Nose is roasted, ashy and has some chocolate. Flavor is massive cold coffee and dark chocolate. Medium bodied. It didnt blew me away!
 Rerate RBESG Rome, 2010. Coffee flavor is amazing. Smooth and roasted. Much better this time. 3,1 - 3,6

Bottle 22fl.oz.Clear dark brown color with a average to large, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, beige head. Aroma is moderate malty, sweet chocolate, coffee, tobacco, light to moderate roasted. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and bitter with a long duration, chocolate sweet, coffee. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20100314]
Bottle at Papsøs - Thanks. Black - offwhite head. Coffee, high coffee, chocolate, bitterness, medium hoppy, vegetables, fruity, grassy, sharpness, grounded coffee, cocoa, nutty, dryness.

Bottled. A dark brown beer with a thin dark brown head. The aroma has strong notes of cocoa and coffee as well as medium notes of roasted malt and caramel. The flavor is sweet with notes of coffee, cocoa, roasted malt, nuts, prunes, and some caramel, leading to a dry coffee finish.

Bottle at Papsø, my rating # 9000.
Black coloured with a meidum sized beige head.
Sweet and roasted aroma of freshgrinded coffee with notes of chocolate.
Sweet and roasted flavour of dfreshgrinded coffee, chocolate, hops and grass.
Roasted finish of coffee.
Nice.

very dark brown, small light brown head.
very strong chocolate aroma, also some toffee, faint roasted grains.
flavor is cofee, chocolate, roasted grains, well balanced, chocolate is in the background
Dark brown with a large deep beige head. Aroma had hard roasted malt, espresso and dark chocolate. Sweet flavour with burned malt, dark chocolate and espresso notes. Finished sweet. Not bad.

Bottle 65. Courtesy of bu11zeye. Pours a very dark brown with a reddish hue and a dense and creamy beige head leaving a neat lacework. Very distinct coffee aroma. Medium body, sweet hard roasted malt, coffee and a little sweet vanilla. The coffee really shines here without leaving a massive bitterness. Quite some roast in the finish with a discreet bitterness. 140310

22 fl oz bottle. Pours dark brown to black with a small tan head. Aroma is spiced, roasted and herbal coffee. Bitter, roasted and coffee flavoured. Lingering dark malty and roasted flavoured with a nice and forefront coffee flavour. Smooth coffee and dark malty flavoured finish with a subdued sweetness.

Bottle from a trade with fogdog I believe.  Pours a clear dark brown with a large fading tan head.  Sweet plum, ample coffee over some smoke and roast.  Medium bodied, spicy coffee, lots of soft bitter cocoa. Finishes with some more roast and coffee.  Pretty tasty.

25.4 oz bottle, September 2008.  Dark brown with a foamy tan head.  Nose is coffee bean, dark chocolate and hay.  Medium body with a fizzy tang.  Taste is mostly coffee, kind of acidic.  Bakers chocolate and muted citrus peel in a dry ashy finish.

intro! .. has a slight spritz .. brown sugar and oil aromas .. . smooth .. . abv well masked .. . very smooth actually .. . black as the 8ball .. . great foam attributes .. .you a winner haha you a winner haha.

750mL, corked and caged, 2008 vintage.  Poured deep brown with a dense cap of medium tan head.. looked great in the glass!  The aroma picked up fresh, wet ground coffee paired with toasted earthy character, vanilla, and just a hint of molasses.. deep down was some sour, greener coffee.  The flavor was centered around the coffee, with roasted mocha and molasses notes at the core and coffee bitterness surrounding.. some dark chocolate and vanilla influence.. light oak and coffee sourness on the edges and a touch of dark spice that balanced well against the malts on the long finish.  Medium-plus bodied with high-ish carbonation on the palate.. well-balanced and tasty!

Cask Stillage from the Jug at the GABF, Colorado Convention Center 26/09/2009
Big coffee roast aroma. Small white head. Dark coloured rich on the palate strong in alcohol and hoppy with a crisp and bitter dry roast finish.
Pours dark brown with a light brown head.  Smells of coffee, some chocolate, roasty.  Tastes of coffee grinds, some nutty hints.  Not balanced.
Deep brown almost black with light tan head and lace. Aroma is big coffee. Coffee, dry flavor, medium malt bitter finish. A tad thin but very nice carbonation.
Stfun with a great bonus! Nearly a black pour.  Tan head.  Coffee galore! chocolate makes its appearance as well.  Roasted and a bit of bittnerness. Nice damn beer.

750 mL bottle shared at Logans 2009 pre-GABF Party.  Black pour with a light tan head.  Big, coffee aroma.  Coffee and dark chocolate flavors.  Its crazy that I had to go all the way to Denver to try a beer brewed in my home state but this is really excellent.

22 oz bottle acquired via trade. Poured out a deep brown, nearly black with a hefty tan head. This bottle was actually quite the gusher, which you dont see every day from a stout. The aroma was coffee, coffee, coffee with a light bit of chocolate and some roasted malt. The flavor was also hefty coffee, with the chocolate, roasted malts and a wee bit of smokiness lingering in the background. This beer was a little too carbonated for me and had too thin a mouthfeel, but it was still tasty. All in all somewhat of a disappointment however. 

Edit: Forgot to mention that I consumed this with my good friend Juan Valdez, which did make the event a little more special.

Bomber.  Pours a dark brown-black with a substantial light brown head.  Interesting coffee aroma (like a more fragrant Tanzanian Peaberry) with chocolate and roasted malt.  This is a true pleasure to drink with flavors of sweet chocolate, coffee, malt, and a hint of smoke.  The rather bitter finish, however, prevents me from rating this higher.  On the other hand, this is enjoyable enough to cause a serious distraction when operating heavy machinery such as a supertanker.
Big mocha aroma.  Nice dry flavor with a lot of nice rich coffee notes and hints of super dark coffee.

Time to catch up before BCTC.  Bottle at CL Rosso release.  Thanks to all the RBers and BAs that brought great beer.  Chocolate covered esspresso bean aroma.  Chocolate roasted coffee bitterness, and then my notes say, "oblgerrhust."

UPDATED: AUG 1, 2009 Courtesy of Avalon68 via trade
Bottle:  The aroma is loaded with chocolate (dark chocolate and chocolate syrup) along with some light roasted coffee.  It pours a dark brown with a moderate beige head with good retention.  The flavor starts with a quick dose of dark chocolate and chocolate syrup.  The finish has a very nice roasted coffee presence.  Medium bodied with soft carbonation.  This is what Southern Tier Mocha should have been.
22oz. Pour is inky black with a fluffy brown head. Aromas full of coffee, roasted malts, and vanilla. Flavor is a straight up coffee bomb! Really drinkable and nice.
user_location: back in NJ!, New Jersey, USA

text:
Thanks to Jonas for sharing

black pour with coffee ground flavor and flavors of coffee and chocolate, this was an interesting brew

Bottle shared by ShareANevada.

Poured black color with an average brown frothy head that mostly lasted with good lacing. Moderate roasted malt,chocolate and small alcohol aroma. Medium to full body with a smooth texture and flat carbonation. Medium to heavy sweet roasted coffee flavor with a medium to heavy bittersweet finish of moderate to long duration.

Good complex stout.

Very nice coffee smell on the nose.  On the palate I get coffee, small chocolate but mostly coffee.  I feel as though it is medium bodied, but most would argue more full bodied.  Nice beer definitely recommended.

22 oz. bottle. Purs out black with a big creamy brown head. Huge coffee aroma, like walking into Starbucks. Theres also some bitter chocolate, and maybe some dark fruits. Full body, some astringency, and a fairly dry palate. Coffee flavor dominates to the point of being overwhelming, some underlying dark malty sweetness takes the edge off. This would be lot better if the coffee werent quite so assertive.

bomber from stfun...

pours barely transparent woody dark blackish brown with a huge cafe au lait colored head.

it smells of well toasted  coffee beans, malt, caramel and lots of nuts. 

the same crafted coffee is in the flavor... and lots of it! it is not bitter, harsh or sour... id really like to try the coffee on its own... anyway, the beer has other flavors of dark dried fruit/prunes, heavy roast, grass and buttery caramel covered toasted walnuts with a touch of acidity on the finish.

it is fairly full bodied though it is oddly carbonated...it is very high, soft and sudsy. it builds and fills my mouth like that spray in insulation. this detracts from what is an otherwise solid brew. 8/4/8/2/14/3.6
Wow. A mouthful of coffee. Extremely rich and powerful. Lots of roast. Subtle tastes of tart and hops. Carbonated. Very nice overall.

Source:  22 oz bomber shared at a tasting. Glass: Snifter. Appearance: Black pour with a two finger brown head.  Aroma:  Coffee and roasted malt.  Earthy hop notes. Flavor: coffee and nuts with roasted malt and a hint of chocolate. Palate:  full bodied with soft carbonation and a creamy mouthfeel.Overall:  Good stout.  Need to bottle in sixers instead of 22 ozers. .

Bottle.  Pours opaque with a large, frothy, dark brown head, mostly lasting with fair lacing.  Aroma is heavy malt (coffee, chocolate, nutty), light hop (grass), average yeast (leather) with notes of tar, charcoal, prune, and dates.  Full bodied, creamy texture, lively carbonation, and a bitter finish.  Long duration, moderate sweetness, acidity, and bitterness.

Bottle acquired via trade.  A really great coffee stout.  Black with a nice tan head.  Aroma is lots of fresh coffee and roast.  Great coffee flavor with roasted malt and bitter cocoa.  Smooth palate, carbonation medium.

Bottle courtesy of RealityDeviant on 04/30/2009. Dark black body with faint ruby highlights and a medium creamy light brown head. Big coffee, roast and spicy hop aroma. Big coffee flavor with some light roast and caramel a with a bit of bitter background. Medium light body with moderate carbonation, though almost lighter than the aroma implies.

Compliments of the Monsignor himself, the indelible, DrBayern!  Al consumed at Eds beer palace in the area of croatan.  The beer poured pitch black pour with light ruby hints at the edges. Thin cover of tan head, dark roasted aroma of coffee beans. Very light carbonation and body. The flavour was of deep earth and dirt, dark coffee beans.  Extremely well made and enjoyable.  Complete yummos !
user_location: The Crystal Coast, North Carolina, USA

text: bottle, black brown color with big milkshake foam, aroma is mostly coffee and some malt and roast nuts, flavors of dry cocoa, coffee, hazelnuts, finish is a little short or this would have been really nice

The best part of waking upo is some more Valdez in your glass!  Enjoyed this bottle courtesy of the ever sharing Drbayern, the Uncles Steve and Tom, our New beer Pimp Brian, and Dancin Paul.  This beer was BLACK, with a tan, fluffy, lacy head.  aroma was that of a fine cup of coffee.Taste was of coffee, with some chocolate and malt.  The mouthfeel was great!

On draft at the brewery.  Just a massive amount of coffee.  Since Im not a coffee drinker, it was a little much.  But it did have a light chocolatey sweetness.  Very damn good for what they were going for.
Bottle from bruisin ales recommended by jsh12bama.  Hes a lightweight, so I shouldve expected a lightweight brew.  Tons of coffee and not much else.  A little watery.

UPDATED: MAY 15, 2009 bomber from bruisin ales. pours slightly thin for a stout, very dark brown, with a thick, light tan head a great lacing. aroma is great with huge, dark roasted coffee, dark chocolate, and a touch of smoke and vanilla. flavor is simply delicious with amazing rich, dark coffee, more chocolate, roasted pistachios, toffee, and just a touch of sugary, vanilla sweetness and a long, dry, bitter coffee finish. definitely the most coffee forward brew ive tasted. palate is smooth, medium bodied, and just a touch too highly carbonated for a stout. overall, a delicious brew that proves organic beers can play with the big boys.

YERM.  Awesome coffee just-regular stout.  Sometimes I forget that people still brew just-regular stouts instead of 11%, thick-as-mud imperial stouts.  Honestly, its 20x easier to find a good imperial stout as it is to find a good pils.  This is a good just-regular stout.  My first Pisgah beer.

Fantastic.  The coffeeist of all the coffee beers. Low ABV helps drinkability, but takes away a bit from overall happiness for the bomber.  Very dark and quite thick.  Without knowing the ABV, you would assume it was quite the imperial.

WELL worth seeking out.
Pours black with a thick brown head. Aroma is creamy milk coffee. Sweet cream taste followed by an excellent coffee bitterness.
(750ml bottle)  Pours and opaque black body with a medium tan head.  Aroma of coffee, roasted malt, and dark chocolate.  Flavor of coffee, roasted malt, cream, and caramel.
bottle thanks to bu11zeye.  poured a dark brown/black with a tan head.  aroma of coffee, chocolate, and brownies.  flavor was coffee, dark roast, and alcohol.  slick body with high carbonation.

Pisgah week, part 2,from Bruisin Ales.  Pours choclate brown and thickish looking with big chocolate head.  Aroma is coffee, and chocolate.  There is a lot of coffee in the taste, I am not a coffee drinker but appreciated what it was, and a stout very well integrated with coffee.  Of course on the thicker mouthfeel side though still smooth, not a sipper.  Like a 1.5 stout not a RIS.

Bottle shared by MrP00tz. Thanks Mister!  Pours dark, dark brown with a small tan head that leaves an appropriate lace. Nose is straight up coffee, light cocoa, roasted malts. Good, but simple. Flavor is the same, nice coffee presence, without being too overbearing like some in the style. A little overcarbonated like most Pisgah beers, but a very nice, dark, and roasty coffee stout overall!!!!

When Pootz thinks of Pisgash, Pootz thinks of dank, dirty, granola-eating, chaco-wearing, nag-champa smelling, organic hippies. But these hippies sure do know how to brew. Pootz has waited many a day to try this here brew and its been a while since he rated a brew at all so hes in quite the jolly mood at this here moment. Pours brown with big sudsy yellow tan head.  Pleasant, earthy, fresh coffee aroma, some roasted malt, light cocoa.  Pootz likes. Flavor is all coffee, smooth and creamy. Could probably use a tad less carbonation, but overall a very well put together coffee stout.   Score one for the  green team!

Bottle thanks to bu11zeye. Pours a deep, dark brown/black with somewhat tan head. Aroma of fresh ground coffee, very nice. Flavor of fresh ground coffee, dark roast, some what sweet. Mouth feel is medium-heavy body with medium carbonation. Overall, very good stuff!
Bottle thanks to bu11zeye. Black in color with a good sized beige head. aroma is of coffee grounds and chocolate. Taste is espresso, coffee, cream and roasted malts...lightly sweetened.

Bottle, thanks to WeeHeavySD! Pours a deep black with a tan head. Big aroma, lots of coffee, with malt and chocolate. Rich taste, starts sharp and grassy, with some malt and chocolate, then picks up a ton of coffee, both dry and bitter. Lingering bitter coffee. Wonderful.

Bottle thanks to bu11zeye. Pours a dark black brown color with a medium large bone colored head. Notes of dirt and fresh coffee, and cigarettes. Just a coffee bomb all over the place and it turns out pretty good.

Bottle thanks to bu11zeye. A gusher surprisingly. Pours with a huge, creamy mocha colored head over a pitch black body. Great lace and full retention.  Tons of really dark roast on the aroma, cinnamon and vanilla. Taste is leather, roast, vanilla, mocha roast, and no alcohol at all. One of my favorite coffee beers I have tried so far. Syrupy mouthfeel (especially for the ABV), with medium carbonation.

Bottle. Nose-dry cold pressed coffee, fresh wet coffee grounds. Body-dark brown, nearly opaque with a thick ring of bubbles. Taste-perfect coffee, dry must, dusty, sawdust, high stinging CO2, cigarette smoke.
UPDATED: MAR 20, 2009 Bottle thanks to bu11zeye.  Black pour with a thi khaki head.  Creamy chocolate nose with roasted malts.  Easy on the palate with a deep dark chocolate flavor.

C&PLYFOTD: Bottle, courtesy fogdog. Brownish pour, with a thick head and lacing. Nose has tons of coffee, hazelnut, dry grain. Flavor is mostly coffee, dark grain, slight chocolate and a very smooth dry coffee roast in the finish. Very smooth overall, balanced well, yummy.

Courtesy dchmela.  Black pour, broken tan head.  Heavy powdered cocoa aroma, licorice, almond, alcohol.  Thinnish on the palate.  Taste is pretty mild, chocolate malt flavor, less straight cocoa, mild finish.

bottle shared at February Beer Advocate Tasting.  Pours black with a light brown head.  Nose is wonderful roast coffee.  Taste is coffee, but doesnt measure up to the aroma.  Mouthfeel is thin with some carbonation.  Disappointed, considering what I had heard about it.

Intense aroma of coffee, roasted malt and bitter chocolate.  Very black pour.  A pffft at the open leads to a fairly carbonated beer - possibly too much primer.  Lots of coffee and  burnt caramel, mixed with roasted malts, including an abundance of Black Malt.  Pretty darn good.

650 ml, Jan 09 vintage. Gushes a bit on opening. Tar-black pour with a large head that settles to a lasting quarter-inch foam. Nose of espresso, milk chocolate and caramel. Flavor is mostly espresso with a little milk chocolate and a hint of sour cream. A bit of char hiding in the finish. Nice drippy lacing on the glass. Medium-heavy body is roasty-dry, drinkably watery, but just a little too frothy with carbonation.

Black colored ale, with ruby edges. Very frothy head varies in color from light tan to dark tan. One dimensional nose smells of espresso, but lacks malt aromatics. Flavor has some complexity to it and tastes nice, but is still dominated by the coffee addition and doesnt have much malt depth. That being said, its suave and has some finesse to it. It even finishes pretty well. Its a nice ale.

Sept. 2008 bottle consumed on 1/24/09. Beer pours black with brownish head. Head was thin and quickly fizzled away like soda. Has a great coffee taste, but the body is a little thin. The beer is very drinkable and if you like coffee its worth a try.

Thanks to Santa Deuane for this one. Once I struggled to get the cork out of this bottle. 
I poured the bottle into a snifter and it produced a two finger coco colored Head that seems to be lasting. The body of course was a big black bomb 

The first thing I smelled was coffee and chocolate right from the pour. After a bit I got a little sour yeast but not much

Flavors are Coffee that is about it till it warms. Not as sweet as Oscura, but the mouthfeel reminded me of it. It is a little light in the feel for an Imperial but ample carbonation maybe to much. Back to the flavor a little sweetness from the malts keeps it from being to bitter. Then some dark chocolate comes out as it warms.

A good coffee stout I really think there should be a separate category for these. The number of them seems to be climbing. Good drinkability I finished the bomber with no problems at all. Took my time and enjoyed it on this cloudy afternoon thanks again Santa

UPDATED: JUN 28, 2009 Bottle from Ross. Pours a deep brown/black with a mud brown head. Aroma of wet coffee grounds and roasted malts. Mouthfeel is medium, but with a feathery texture. Flavor is fairly straight forward, coffee, dark roasted malts, and a hint of char. Moderate attenuation. Finish is dry, but has an off flavor on the finish that I do not care for- acetaldehyde? Definitely not worth the $11 price tag for a 750ml. I tried a another bottle at a Nashville BA tasting and it was infected.

courtesy of our friendly tpd975.
Pours dark brown with tan head.
Aroma is loaded with coffee and oat.
Taste, lots of coffee and malts with a light hoppy aftertaste.
This one beer has coffee all over it. Very drinkable and enjoyable.

Another big thanks to tpd975 for bringing this tasty brew. Pours dark brown with mocha head. The aroma is big bold dark roasted coffee with burnt malts in the background. Smells like a cup o joe. The taste is much the same with a wave of carbonation bringing in instant dark roasted coffee followed by burnt malts. I enjoy the fairly high quality dark roasted coffee given it a rich taste.

Bottle courtesy of one of the Tampa crews finest, tpd975. Pours a very dark brown with a one finger tan head that leaves good lacing. Aroma is full on coffee with a touch of roasted malt and chocolate. Taste is the same as the aroma. Medium mouthfeel with a mild amount of bitterness and smooth alcohol. Very one sided but a damn fine coffee beer.

UPDATED: FEB 19, 2009 Fantastic brew if you enjoy coffee stouts. Pours pitch black. Strong coffee in the aroma. Flavor is awesome mixture of coffee and chocolate, roasted barley and grains. Notes of lactose swim in and out. Delicious.

UPDATED: DEC 7, 2008 750ml bottle from fogdog......wow this looks fantastic.  pours black even when held up to the light and not to mention a huge light tan head to accompany it....  aroma or fresh coffee grounds..... flavors of fresh roasted coffee and very little of nothing else which isnt a bad thing. carbonation is pretty lively maybe a little too much but still really drinkable. i could have this as my every day morning coffee fix.  wonder what would win between this and founders breakfast....hmmmm.

POurs dark brown with a light brown head.  Spicy nice with quite a bit of cocoa and older coffee character.  The flavor is like one of those canned coffee drinks you get at the gas station.  Pretty thin and prickly.  Dry finish.

Corked and Caged Bottle from BDR I believe, this brewery has great name significance for me as the sleep away camp I went to is quite close to Pisgah Forest.  Anyway.  Woah, what a damn amazing nose.  This beer smelled amazing from when I first popped the cork.  Nose is rich and roasty with a lot of coffee.  Pour is really pretty nice big black with a huge lacing brown head.  Taste is freaking amazing, this is a big killer coffee stout, its so damn good, and rich and smooth and full of coffee.  This is a stellar stellar stout!!

Bottle courtesy Durhambeer. Thin black pour with a thin tan head. Huge coffee aroma with hints of cocoa. Nice coffee dominated taste with a good malt balance and hints of chocolate. Great body and drinks very smooth, a real tasty beer wih an awesome aroma.

Bottle shared by Crosling, thanks.  Poured a deep brown color with a moderate beige head that slowly diminished to a layer.  Aroma of coffee grounds, roasted malt, and some light smoke.  Smooth, moderately sweet entry with some light chocolate that is overpowered by coffee beans and roasted malt.  Finishes moderately sweet with some light roast.  Moderate carbonation, decent mouthfeel.  An alright stout, but it didn’t really distance itself from most of the other coffee stouts I have had.

UPDATED: JAN 21, 2009 Bottle This beer rocks! Pitch black ale with a small, creamy, beige head. Great retention. Rich, chocolaty, coffee with cream aroma. Full-bodied and very silky with soft carbonation. Tastes like a lightly sweetened mocha latte. Burnt, bitter, dry finish.

Bottle.  Pours out a dark black color with a thick tan head on it that lasts to the end of the bottle.  Awesome pour, havent seen a beer that looked like this in a long time.  Smell is sweet, with a little bit of chocolate and a huge amount of coffee.  Sort of like Peche Mortel Light.  Taste is very smooth and incredibly easy to drink.  Thick yet not too thick to session.  Dangerously drinkable, I could see myself drinking alot of this and not remember my name.  This is up there with the top beers in this category.  On par with Kalamazoo.
pours out a black color with a thick tan head.  aroma smells like a coffee shop.  flavor is very nice.  like a large glass of cold coffee.  great brew.

Thanks dchmela!  Like the black as oil waters of the Alaskan coastline, Valdez pours like something you’d expect to be stuck in seal fur.  Like the waters are vacant of marine life, Valdez is vacant of sweetness.  Slightly over-roasted and full of coffee, this needs a little more sweetness to balance it out.  Dryness and cocoa flavors linger in the mouth long after the medium bodied beer goes down the hatch.  Certainly not a bad beer, just slightly too roasted for my tastes.

Courtesy dchmela.  The pour yields a deep, dark chocolate brown body with a small, well retained blanket of tan colored foam.  Random, spotty lacing marks the glass.  The aroma is big and roasty, with dry, dark cocoa and rich, lightly creamed coffee notes.  Flavors follow suit, showing that same, beautiful pairing of semi-sweet dark cocoa and bold, roasted espresso.  Some earthy hop bitterness further balanced the swetness of the chocolate malts.  Straightforward, but delicious.  The only major detractor here is the palate, which is substantial enough, but is a good deal overly carbonated.  Tasty brew!
Big coffee and chocolate aroma. Dark brown with a tight ring of foam. Roast and coffee flavors, with a medium body.  Easy lightly roasted finish.

Sampled from 750 ml bottle during Surly D-Day. Pours an opaque dark brown brew with a creamy beige head that has some nice retention and lacing. Aroma of mostly coffee and dark chocolate that overpowers any dark malts. Taste is medium bodied, very low carbonation with more coffee flavors with a hint of chocolate, vanilla and caramel. Finish has a mild metallic texture with a coffee and dark malt aftertaste.

Strong coffee aroma, milk chocolate, and caramel. 
Pours black with a cream colored thick head. 
Coffee coffee cofee flavor, with a hint of caramel. 
Palate is watery and coffee like. 
I love coffee flavored beer. But I wish it had more depth.
Bottle.  Pours a black with 1 finger creamy brown head.   Chocolate, vanilla, caramel malt.  Coffee bitter with a dry finish.  Toffee, has a slight metallic flavor as it warmed that was off.
Shared by Rciesla.  Thanks broski.  Pretty straightforward coffee stout.  As it warms, finish gets ugly.  Better cold.

Bottle at the 2008 pre-Brewers’ Jam warmup. Pours black with amber edges and a thin brown head. The aroma is unapologetically freshly ground coffee (not the beverage, the ground beans). The flavor is very deep, earthy coffee with some distant stout flavors behind it. This is more coffee than beer, really, but I love a high quality coffee, and this hits the mark.

Bottle shared by Suttree at the Pre-Brewer’s Jam Tasting. Pours black with a thin tan head. Big aromas of fresh ground roast coffee beans. The flavor finds lots of coffee with a nut and dark chocolate backing. Medium body. Sweet with a coffee bitter aftertaste. Very nice.

Suttree’s 2008 Pre-Brewer’s Jam Tasting.  Sample from a bottle thanks to Suttree.  Pitch black pour with light ruby hints at the edges.  Thin cover of tan head, dark roasted aroma of coffee beans.  Very light carbonation and body.  Taste of deep earth and dirt, dark coffee beans.

bottle.  Huge light brown creamy head into black body with good lacing present.  aromas of strong coffee and moderate bitter cocoa with some vinousness.  flavor is initially initially bittersweet into a muted sweet.  lively carbonation (actually running wild).  long finish duration.  almost velvety texture.  damn fine stout.

Bottle from Bruisin Ales. Tan head. Aroma is promising and wafts a bit from the glass. Mainly coffee with a little bit of chocolate. This is a surprisingly light bodied stout but still decent in flavor.  Creamy texture.  Coffee and bittersweet chocolate flavors.  Finish is slight cocoa and leaves a faintly sweet mouthfeel.  Hopped up aftertaste as well.  Light body and lower alcohol make this easy to drink.

Bottle shared at recent tasting.  Thanks!Pours a dark black color with a tan head.  Smell is coffee, roasty malt, and a lot more coffee.
Taste is tart, bright and bold coffee all the way.  Moderately bittered and with a bit of a dark chocolate flavor as well.  Medium mouthfeel and slightly bubbly carbonation.  I thought this was definitely enjoyable, but without knowing it was so highly regarded, I wasn’t blown away.  Wouldn’t mind having again, though.

C&C 750 shared by Alraomon. Thanks Sean! Pours an opaque dark brown color with a massive brown head. Moderate retention and decent lacing. The head had huge bubble variety and lots of volatility, Nice to watch. Aroma of earthy bitter coffee notes. Some cocoa. Taste is huge bitter coffee with chocolate, caramel and vanilla to sweeten it up a bit. Full bodied.

750 ml bottle.  Pours black with a creamy three finger brown head.  Roasted malt and coffee aroma.  Flavor is similiar, bitter chocolate, expresso brean and roastiness.  Dry finish and a bit thin for what I expect from a stout, however, it makes this stout very easy to drink.

Bottle.  Pours deep brown with little head, light lacing.  Aroma is nice and roasted, with coffee & bitter chocolate.  Taste is nice, roasted, and smooth.  Mouthfeel is smooth and creamy.  Finish is little bitter.  A nice beer.

bottle, from brewery. Good aroma. Coffee, chocolate, peanutty. Brownish black color, good head that faded quickly, minor lacing. Bitter sweet flavor, coffee really takes over. little brown sugar, Medium body, smooth creamy mouthfeel, though it’s carbonation made it expand as I swirled it around my mouth. Tasty beer, on tap it probably would of scored 8/4/7/4/15 if I had kept notes at the fest or at Barley’s. The carbonation took away from it, it seemed stickier on tap.
user_location: the Containment Area, North Carolina, USA

text: Sampled at Brewgrass 2008.  Pours a chocolate hazy color with no head.  Plenty of coffee in the aroma with a bit of coco making itself known.  A delicious drink to be sure.  Very flavorful for a regular strength stout.  Coffee, chocolate covered espresso beans all in a great balance with a touch of residual sweetness.  Creamy medium mouth feel and body.
(draft) Brown-black body atop brown head.  Aroma is moderately sweet, coffee, light caramel.  taste is medium sweet, coffee, roast, some caramel.  Low carbonation, medium body.

Oh sweet Jesus, this is good stuff.  Deep dark brown pour with dark tan bubbly head.  Perhaps the freshest coffee flavor and aroma that I’ve come across in a beer.  Not too sweet nor too alcoholic; this is actually a very drinkable coffee stout.  Some nice roastiness, good bitter flavor and a hint of hops, and some chocolate notes as well.  Great beer.

750mL corked and caged bottle poured into a tulip.  Pours dark, dark brown out of the bottle and settles pitch black in the glass with a massive three-finger tan head that shows great retention and lacing.
Aroma is coffee, coffee and more coffee.  There is more than a hint of dark roasted malts underlying the coffee but the aroma of freshly ground coffee steals the shows in the this one.
The taste is also big on the coffee, but with a very slight bitterness in the finish.  The dark malts are more evident than in the aroma, but the sweet roasted coffee shine through again.  If you like coffee, you’ll love this stuff.
Creamy and medium bodied mouthfeel with tons of carbonation that just leaves your mouth tingling with that cup-of-joe taste throughout.
If reviewing this beer as a imperial stout, it may be the most drinkable I’ve ever had in the style.  I tend to think of it more of a stout and a half instead of a double, but it’s damn fine stuff either way.  Highly recommended!

750ml from the good folks at Bruisin Ales. I’ve been wanting to try this one for some time. Lovely coffee nose, not simply hardcore roastage but actual bean richness. Body is big and the head is lively and lasting. Really fine and rich stout at the core, a bit sticky with abundant chocolate malts dominating. Coffee complements nicely and is well integrated, not just a lamination. Creamy mouthfeel, a real treat of a beer.

UPDATED: SEP 8, 2012 
Date: April 21, 2008
Mode: Growler
Source: Tasting, Cellar Party
Appearance: solid black, fine tan head, streaks of drippy lace
Aroma: strong dark chocolate aroma with roasted and coffee characters
Body: creamy body
Flavor: rich chocolate and coffee flavor, touch of roasted brings in a bitterness, hint of dark caramel and milky sweetness for balance

Date: April 24, 2009
Mode: bottle
Source: tasting
Aroma: big coffee aroma, lota of roasted character, dark chocolate
Flavor: rich chocolate and coffee flavor, long dark chocolate bitterness

Date: September 05, 2010
Mode: growler
Source: brewery
Score: 3.4 to 3.6
as rich and wonderful as ever

Date: August 31, 2012
Mode: draft
Source: thirsty monk
huge awesome coffee, just enough caramel sweetness to balance, roasted, dark chocolate, long roasty finish, 

Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 7/10; Overall: 15/20
Rating: 3.6/5.0Drinkability: 7/10
Score: **+ /4
Pours a brown color with a brown head.  Aroma is chocolate, roast, coffee, raisins, and some earthiness.  Flavor is malty, chocolate, roast, cream, and a light fruity finish.

Growler: Pours an opaque dark mahogany with a thin, wispy-lacing dark tan head.  Aroma of lightly sweet dark caramel and chocolate malts with a fresh roasted coffee character.  Body starts lightly sweet and fairly full with a toasty caramel and light milk chocolate flavor balanced with a good coffee character.  A pretty good coffe stout, with some lingering roasted notes. But could use a little more fullness and complexity.

12 oz handbottle shared by Hophead75!  Thanks Andrew.  Nice handbottle from Emacgee for sure- everythig about this botlte was perfect.  Pours a nice deep dark brown with some auburn highlights- and a nice creamy lasting tan head.  Aroma is nicely sweet with some caramel amlts, but moslty jsust a ncie smooth coffee tone- more like cappucino-and reminded me of triumph coffee and cream stout from the smoothness and raw fresh coffee.  Great smooth chocolately flavor with more fresh coffee, espresso and cappucino, cream and lactose in teh flavor as well but smooth as hell.  Went down nice and easy and made me want more.  As it warmed everything intensified and got even smoother.  Damn- great stout.

12 oz handbottle from Emacgee. Almost black in color, some light ruby highlights near the bottom of the glass with a small lasting tan head.  Aroma:  Some chocolate, and then just a shitload of coffee- almost smells like they coarsely ground coffee beans and then soaked them in the beer like a dry hop.  In the taste, there is just as much coffee, maybe even more- tons of roasty, earthy coffee, some light touches of  vanilla- light chocolate, but at that point its hard to tell if the chocolate is coming from malt or from the coffee itself.  Medium bodied- the only slight complaint is that there could have been a touch more body to back up all the coffee that was used in this beer, but that is a minor complaint.  Finishes bitter with a moderate amount of hop bitterness, and a good deal of roasted coffee, that lingers like you are chewing on coffee beans...in a good way.   Thanks Ethan!

64oz Growler

7.2%

Get the opportunity to sample my first from Pisgah thanks to Mikesgroove, thanks Mike! Valdez is a fine looking beer! Pours black with some transparency in the form of chestnut highlights at the bottom of the glass. The dirty tan head grew to a solid finger and a half on the pour and fell rather slowly to a skimming and respectable collar. The head leaves a patch or two of lacing here and there.

Wow! This beer is not really beer! Its cold coffee! Well, thats what the aroma suggests anyways. High quality fresh pressed coffee grabs the nose and never lets go. As I stir the head I still get massive coffee but a drop of cream and a pinch of sugar have been added. As the head dies back down its back to black coffee.

Big coffee in the flavor as well, obviously. I wonder if theres any beer in here? Although the coffee is everywhere it just foesnt live up to the intensity of the aroma, which would be near impossible to do. Thats just me being picky though. Finishes with a solid coffee bitterness that grows the more I drink. 

The mouthfeel is a little on the thin side but it actually increases the drinkability. I could be wrong but I think this was created to be a fairly drinkable coffee stout instead of a sippin brew. So keeping that in mind the mouthfeel fits well.

Like I said earlier the drinkability on this stout is up there pretty high. Its already going down far to fast.

I have no idea how the guys at Pisgah squeezed this much coffee into a stout but I commend them for it. Im already jittery and fiending for a cigarette! Id love to see this get bottled in four packs in the future, although that may be a long way off since they only do limited bombers now. Thanks again Mike for sending this tasty treat!

3/14/08

Growler from Bruisin Ales. Pours a dark black brew allowing some light. The head is about a finger thick, creamy, and tan. The aroma was very strong coffee, roasty, chocolate, caramel, light alcohol. Very big coffee flavor, chocolate and caramel also very apparent, roasty, sweet, and  some light waxy hops. Sweet roasty palate.

UPDATED: MAR 1, 2008 From a growler purchased at Bruisin Ales. Black, with a dense, dark tan - almost brown, really - head. Aroma is... Wow. Coffee. and not coffee grounds, or ground coffee, or instant coffee. It smells like fresh brewed coffee. Really amazing. I like coffee stouts, and to my memory this is the best smelling coffee stout Ive had. Id love to do a side by side with Speedway or Peche Mortel. Flavor is equally impressive - Mostly coffee, with a bit of dark cocoa and just a hint of vanilla. There is not a lot of components involved, just a few simple flavors in a rich, smooth, exceedingly well made beer. A definate home run.

Growler, via BA Deuane.  Pours a nice opaque black body with a creamy foamy brown one finger head that had nice retention for a 5 day old growler.  The nose is just spectacular, it smells like freshly ground and brewed dark roast coffee.  It actually smelled more like a quality cup of coffee than the actual cup of coffee they brought me with dessert at the restaurant I took it to.  Some roast and mocha as well, but mainly just coffee.  The flavor is super smooth well extracted coffee, no astringency at all from either the coffee or the malt.  Great depth and complexity to it, this really is all about the coffee, but theres a very solidly made Stout behind it.  Mouthfeel is light to medium bodied with a texture that is maybe a little less robust and less thick than Id like, but the carbonation is just right and its so easily drinkable.  The label on the growler says 7% ABV, but there was no trace of that at all.  Overall, I will admit that I am a huge sucker for coffee beers in general, there are a half dozen coffee beers in my personal Top 50, but this was just excellent any way you cut it.  Way, way, far and away the best organic beer Ive had to date as well.  Big props to Pisgah for this effort!

Let me first say that I love coffee.  If you love coffee then you will love this beer.  If you dont love coffee, then avoid this beer and leave it for coffee lovers like me.  Pitch black in color.  Smells like fresh coffee beans.  Flavor is wonderfully one demensional...COFFEE.  In fact this taste better than most coffees Ive had.  Smooth on the palate.  Maybe a touch to thin.  Pisgah continues to amaze me.

Draught at Pisgah Brewing Co.  The only thing I might criticize about this delicious beverage is that it tastes more like coffee than beer!  At that, it tastes better than any coffee Ive ever had, but then again Im no coffee connoisseur.  I hope they start distributing this to stores in growlers.

Draught at Barleys. The pour is black with a lasting tan head and really nice lacing. The aroma is quite intense in coffee and oats. Its creamy to the tongue and has a very, very dominant coffee flavour. Only in the finish do you start to detect more flavours such as a sweet brown sugar and some cocoa qualities. The finish is lightly bitter, much like a coffee bitterness. This is pretty much coffee. Its very delicious.

UPDATED: MAR 17, 2008 Draught at Barleys. This is a dark beer. It also has a level brownish head that persists the entire time. A sniff reveals big time coffee. Theres no pussy-footing about the coffee character in this, its big time, fresh, dark roasted coffee. Carbonation is spot on and the mouthfeel is a bit creamy and moderately dense. So much coffee flavor has been imparted here that all the nuances are intact along with a creamy, malty sweetness that adds a vanilla wafer and mocha dimension. This is seriously good stuff. Id say its heartier than their imperial stout, roastier for sure, and insanely drinkable.

[march 2, 2008]

On tap at Barleys. This is what a coffee stout should taste like. Loads of coffee is all over the place, but its rich, complex, and dark roasted. The mouthfeel is creamy with plenty of body and an adequate level of chocolate sweetness is present for balance.  Valdez is close to being one dimensional with such heavy emphasis on coffee, but the complexity of said coffee is retained quite well.
pours a black with dark caramel head, slight mocha coffee aroma, good smooth coffee with light finish.  very smooth and well balanced, a more sessionable coffee stout, good stuff.

Draught at Barleys in Asheville.  Listed as a coffee stout.  Big nose of coffee.  Taste is coffee and roasted malt.  It has a sharp coffee bite to it that reminds me of Terrapin Wake n Bake.  Pretty good.

Draught at Barleys in Asheville. The beer was brewed as the 300th batch and uses locally sourced coffee beans. The stout pours black with a large tan head. The aroma smells like coffee. Not of coffee but just like coffee. The taste is the same all coffee with some burnt malt and a bit of sweetness. The lingering aftertaste was also of coffee. In fact I had to keep reminding my self this was beer. If you do not like coffee you will not like this but I thought it was great if a bit one dimensional.
